content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Andrea Barkley: I was born in Munich, Germany, but I moved to the United States when I was just five years old. My family settled in Chicago, and though the transition was tough at first, I always felt like I belonged here. My parents worked hard to make ends meet, and while we never had much, they always made sure I had everything I needed. I remember my mother working multiple jobs, and my father was a mechanic, but neither had much formal education. Still, they instilled in me a strong work ethic and a deep sense of faith. I grew up in a tight-knit neighborhood on the South Side, where everyone knew each other, and I learned early on the value of community. I was always a good student, and I worked my way through college, earning a bachelor's degree in social work. I wanted to help people, especially those from backgrounds similar to mine. I met my husband, Mark, while I was in college, and we've been together ever since. We got married right after I graduated and have been building a life together in Chicago ever since. It's not been easy, but I wouldn't trade it for anything.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Andrea Barkley: There was a moment that really shaped my path, and it happened when I was 17. I had just finished my junior year of high school, and I was working part-time at a local community center while also helping my mom with her cleaning jobs. One day, I met a woman named Mrs. Alvarez, who was a social worker and volunteered there. She noticed how passionate I was about helping others, even though I didn't have much in the way of resources or guidance. She took me under her wing and started mentoring me, showing me what a career in social work could look like. She encouraged me to apply for a scholarship program that would help me attend college, and I was accepted. That moment was a crossroads for me—on one hand, I could have stayed in the cycle of working multiple jobs to support my family, but I chose to take the risk and pursue higher education. It wasn't easy; I had to work full-time during the day and attend classes at night, but I knew it was the right choice. That experience not only changed my life but also gave me the tools to help others in similar situations. I owe a lot of who I am today to that moment and to Mrs. Alvarez.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Andrea Barkley: I think it was a conscious choice, but not one I made in a moment of clarity—it was more like a slow realization. For so long, I just knew I didn't want to be stuck in the same place my parents were, working hard but never really moving forward. When Mrs. Alvarez showed me another path, it felt like a door I hadn't even known was there opened. I remember sitting at my kitchen table that night, looking at the scholarship application, and thinking, 'This is it.' I didn't just want to survive; I wanted to make a difference. I made a promise to myself then that I would take this opportunity, no matter how hard it was. And I did. Every sacrifice I made—every late night, every missed weekend with friends—it all felt worth it because I was choosing my future, not just reacting to the circumstances I was born into.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Andrea Barkley: Absolutely. I think if it weren't for Mrs. Alvarez and the community center, I might not have even considered a path like social work. But I also think there are other organizations and people out there who could have made a difference—maybe a school counselor, a teacher, or even a relative who saw potential in me. The thing is, I grew up in a neighborhood where resources were limited, and not everyone had someone like Mrs. Alvarez in their lives. I think that's why I'm so passionate about my work now. I want to be that person for someone else, to show them that there are options beyond what they might think is possible. I believe in second chances, and I know how much one person's belief in you can change everything.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Andrea Barkley: Yes, I have a partner—his name is Mark, and we've been married for nearly eight years. We met in college, actually, during my first year. He was studying engineering, and I was working part-time at the community center while taking evening classes. We bonded over our shared belief in making a difference in people's lives, even though our paths were very different. We've built a life together in Chicago, and while we both work full-time, we make it a point to prioritize family. We don't have children yet, but we're planning to start a family in the next few years. Mark is incredibly supportive of my work, and I feel lucky to have someone who believes in me as much as he does. Our relationship has been a journey—there have been challenges, especially with balancing work and personal life—but we've always managed to find a way to make it work. I think the biggest thing that keeps us strong is our shared values and the way we both want to create a better future, not just for ourselves, but for the people around us.

Going through these interview questions brought back so many memories and reflections about my journey. It's amazing how much my life has shaped me, from growing up in Chicago to making that pivotal decision at 17 to pursue social work. I never imagined I'd be where I am today, helping others the way Mrs. Alvarez helped me. Talking about my family and Mark reminded me of how important support systems are, and how grateful I am for the people who believe in me. It also made me realize how much I want to pay it forward, to be that guiding hand for someone else who might not see their own potential. These questions weren't just about my past—they were a reminder of why I do what I do every day.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Andrea Barkley: My immediate family includes my parents, Klaus and Ingrid Barkley, and my younger sister, Lena. My parents are still living in Chicago, though they've downsized a bit and now live in a smaller apartment not too far from where I grew up. They've always been proud of me, even though they didn't have much in the way of education or resources to guide them. My father, Klaus, still works as a mechanic, and my mother, Ingrid, retired a few years ago after working multiple jobs for most of her life. They've never been wealthy, but they've always put their family first. My relationship with them is deep and full of love, even though we've had our share of challenges. My sister, Lena, is 14 years younger than me, and she's a junior in high school. She's very different from me—more of a free spirit, but she's also incredibly bright. I try to be a role model for her, just like Mrs. Alvarez was for me. We talk often, and I make sure she knows that no matter what path she chooses, I believe in her. I think my parents are still trying to understand my career in social work, but they've come a long way in accepting it. They see the good I do, and that means more to me than anything.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Andrea Barkley: Of course, there are a few friends and colleagues who have been incredibly important to me over the years. One person who stands out is Sarah, a close friend from college who also works in the nonprofit sector. We met during our first year, and we've been through a lot together—late-night study sessions, job searches, and even some personal struggles. She's been a huge support system for me, and I know I can always count on her. Then there's my colleague, Jamal, who I work with at the community center. He's been a mentor to me in many ways, and his dedication to the work we do inspires me every day. I also have a small group of friends from my childhood who I still keep in touch with, even though life has taken us in different directions. They remind me of where I came from and keep me grounded. I think the people in my life, both family and friends, are what keep me going. They remind me that I'm not alone in this journey, and that makes all the difference.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Andrea Barkley: I live in a neighborhood on the West Side of Chicago, just a few blocks away from the community center where I first started volunteering. It's a diverse area with a mix of long-time residents and newer families moving in. There are a lot of small businesses, local shops, and community organizations that make it feel like a real hub of activity. I love that there's always something going on—whether it's a food truck on the corner, a local art show, or a neighborhood meeting in the park. It's not perfect, of course. There are challenges, like rising rents and gentrification, which have made it harder for some families to stay in the area. But I see so much resilience here, and I want to be part of that. My apartment is in a building that's been around for decades, and I feel connected to the history of the place. It's not fancy, but it's home. I walk to work most days, and I enjoy the sense of community that comes with knowing your neighbors, even if you don't see them every day. It's a place that's shaped me, just like the South Side did when I was growing up, and I hope to give back to it in the same way I was given a chance.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Andrea Barkley: I feel pretty safe here, though I know it's not the same for everyone. There are parts of the neighborhood where things can get rough, especially late at night, but I've never felt threatened in my own part of the block. I think the sense of community plays a big role in that. People look out for each other, and there's a kind of unspoken understanding that we're all in this together. I've seen neighbors help each other out during tough times—whether it's fixing a broken fence, watching kids while someone works late, or just checking in when someone hasn't been seen in a while. It's not perfect, but I think that shared responsibility helps keep things from getting too out of hand. I also try to be part of that, whether it's volunteering at the community center or just saying hello to the people I pass on my walk. Safety, for me, isn't just about not being harmed—it's about feeling like I belong and that my neighborhood is a place where I can grow, not just survive.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Andrea Barkley: Living here has had its challenges, but also a lot of rewards. On the one hand, the cost of living has gone up, and it's harder to find affordable housing than it was when I first moved here. I remember when my apartment was half the rent it is now, and I used to worry about whether I'd be able to stay in the neighborhood long-term. But on the other hand, there's a real sense of purpose here. I feel like I'm part of something bigger, especially with my work at the community center. I get to see the same faces every day—families struggling to make ends meet, kids who need support, seniors who just want to be heard. It's not always easy, but knowing that I can make a difference in someone's life, even in small ways, keeps me going. I also love the diversity of the neighborhood. There are people from all walks of life, and that makes for such rich conversations and experiences. I think the ups and downs are part of what makes this place feel real and alive. It's not about being perfect—it's about being resilient, and I think that's something I've learned from growing up here.

Going through the interview questions about my family, neighborhood, and sense of safety made me reflect on how much my roots in Chicago have shaped who I am today. Talking about Mark and our life together reminded me of the importance of having a partner who believes in your dreams, just like I try to be for my sister Lena. When I described my current neighborhood on the West Side, I realized how much I've grown to appreciate the resilience of the people here, even with all the challenges we face. It's comforting to know that, despite the rising rents and gentrification, there's still a strong sense of community that keeps us connected. And when I thought about safety, I realized it's not just about avoiding danger—it's about feeling seen, heard, and supported by the people around me. These conversations made me more aware of how deeply my environment and relationships influence my work and my sense of purpose.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Andrea Barkley: A typical week for me is pretty structured, but there's always a little flexibility depending on what's going on at the community center. I usually start my day around 6:30 a.m., making coffee and getting ready for work. I walk to the center, which takes about 20 minutes, and I love that walk—it gives me time to clear my head and think about the day ahead. My days can vary quite a bit. Some days, I'm meeting with clients, helping them navigate housing assistance or food programs, while other days I'm organizing events or training new staff. I also have a few hours each week dedicated to administrative work, which can be a bit tedious, but I try to stay focused on the bigger picture. On Fridays, I usually have a bit more flexibility, so I might meet up with friends or spend time with my parents. I also try to set aside time for my own well-being—whether it's going to the gym, reading, or just enjoying a quiet evening at home. I think having a routine helps me stay grounded, especially with everything that's going on in the neighborhood. It's a balance, but I wouldn't trade it for anything.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Andrea Barkley: I work full-time as a social worker at a community center on the West Side, which is just a few blocks from where I live. My schedule is pretty consistent—I start my day around 7:30 a.m., though I usually get up earlier to prepare for the day. I work from 8:00 a.m. to 4:30 p.m., Monday through Friday, but I often stay late when there are meetings or when I need to catch up on paperwork. My job is incredibly varied; some days I'm helping families apply for housing assistance, others I'm counseling individuals dealing with domestic issues, and sometimes I'm just listening to someone who needs to be heard. I also coordinate volunteer programs and organize community events, which can be both exhausting and incredibly rewarding. It's not always easy—there are days when I feel overwhelmed by the number of people in need—but I remind myself why I started this path in the first place. I want to make a difference, just like Mrs. Alvarez did for me. And even though the work is demanding, I feel lucky to be doing something that aligns with my values and gives me a sense of purpose.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Andrea Barkley: Outside of work, I also have a few routines that keep me balanced. Every Sunday, I try to spend the morning with my parents, whether it's having breakfast together or just sitting on the porch and catching up. It's a small thing, but it helps me stay connected to where I came from. I also have a weekly yoga class that I try to attend, even if it's just once a week—it helps me unwind and stay focused. And I make it a point to spend time with Lena, my sister, even if it's just a phone call or a quick visit. She's going through a tough time in high school, and I want to be there for her, just like I hope someone was there for me when I was her age. I also try to cook at least one meal from scratch each week, mostly because I grew up in a household where meals were always made from scratch, and it reminds me of home. It's these little routines that keep me grounded, especially when the work gets heavy.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Andrea Barkley: One of the biggest changes to my daily routine has been incorporating more time for self-care, especially as I've been planning to start a family with Mark. We've been talking a lot about how we want to be present for our children, and that means I've had to be more intentional about balancing work, rest, and personal time. I've started waking up a little earlier now—not just to make coffee, but to do a short meditation or journaling session. It's something I used to skip because I was always in a rush, but I've realized that taking those few minutes in the morning helps me feel more centered throughout the day. I've also been trying to eat more mindfully, which has meant cooking more meals at home instead of grabbing something on the way to work. It's been a small but meaningful shift, and I think it's helping me feel more grounded as I prepare for the next chapter of my life.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Andrea Barkley: Well, we're not there yet, but we've been talking a lot about what that future will look like. If we do have children, I imagine their days would be pretty structured, especially since I want them to have a strong foundation. They'd start their day with breakfast, maybe something simple like pancakes or eggs, and then head off to school. I'd make sure they have everything they need—lunch, a backpack, and a reminder to stay curious. After school, depending on their interests, they might have activities like soccer, art classes, or maybe even volunteering at a community center like the one I work at. I want them to understand the value of helping others, just like I did. Mark and I are both pretty busy, but we've talked about making sure we have family dinners most nights, even if it's just a quick meal. I think the most important thing is that they feel loved, supported, and that they know they can talk to us about anything. I hope to give them the same kind of guidance I received from Mrs. Alvarez, and maybe even more—because I know how much it meant to me.

Going through the interview questions from 11 to 15 made me reflect deeply on how much my life has been shaped by the people and places I've known. Talking about my family, especially Mark and Lena, reminded me of the importance of having a support system that believes in you and encourages you to be your best self. It also made me think about how my neighborhood, with all its challenges and strengths, has played a big role in who I am today. I realized that living here isn't just about the struggles—it's about the resilience, the connections, and the sense of purpose that come with being part of a community that's constantly evolving. It also made me appreciate the small routines I have, like my morning walks, my yoga classes, and my time with my parents. These things may seem simple, but they ground me and help me stay focused on what matters most. I think these conversations helped me see how deeply my environment and relationships influence my work and my sense of self. It's a reminder that I'm not just surviving—I'm thriving, and I want to make sure I pass that on to others, especially Lena, as she grows up.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Andrea Barkley: In terms of my health, I would say I'm generally in pretty good shape, though I wouldn't call myself athletic. I try to stay active with my weekly yoga classes, and I've started going for longer walks in the neighborhood, especially now that the weather is nicer. I used to be pretty sedentary, especially during college when I was juggling work and school, but I've made a conscious effort to prioritize my well-being in recent years. I do have some chronic issues, like occasional back pain from sitting at my desk for long hours, and I've had to be more mindful of my posture. I also deal with stress from work, which sometimes manifests as sleep issues or anxiety, but I've started practicing mindfulness and journaling to help manage that. I've been seeing a therapist once a month, which has been really helpful in processing the emotional weight of my job. I think it's important to be honest about the challenges, but I also try to focus on the positive—like how I feel more in control of my health now than I did a few years ago. It's a work in progress, but I'm committed to taking care of myself so I can keep doing the work I love and be there for my family.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Andrea Barkley: What makes it easy to stay healthy for me is having a routine that includes movement, like my yoga classes and morning walks, and knowing that taking care of myself is just as important as taking care of others. It's also the support system I have—whether it's my therapist, my friends, or even just the quiet moments with my parents. What makes it hard, though, is the constant stress from work. There are days when I come home so drained that the last thing I want to do is cook a healthy meal or go for a walk. I have to remind myself that if I don't take care of my health, I won't be able to keep helping the people I care about. It's a balancing act, but I'm learning to be kinder to myself in the process.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Andrea Barkley: In the past two years, I've had a few health challenges that I didn't expect. About a year ago, I started experiencing persistent fatigue and some digestive issues that I initially brushed off as stress. But after a few months of it not improving, I went to the doctor, and it turned out I had a mild case of hypothyroidism. It was a bit of a shock, honestly. I never thought something like that could affect me, but once I started taking the medication, I felt like a weight had been lifted. It made me realize how important it is to listen to my body and not ignore the signs. Along with that, I've had some flare-ups of the back pain I mentioned before, especially after long days at work. I've been seeing a physical therapist now, and it's helped a lot. It's funny, though—I used to think I was too busy to take care of myself, but now I see that taking care of my health is part of being able to take care of others. I'm still learning, but I'm trying to be more proactive about it now.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Andrea Barkley: Honestly, there have been moments when my health challenges made things a bit more difficult, especially with the demands of my job. When I was first diagnosed with hypothyroidism, I felt like I was constantly running on empty, and it made it harder to stay focused during long days at the community center. I remember one time when I was working with a family who was going through a really tough housing crisis, and I felt so drained that I almost couldn't keep up with the emotional weight of the situation. It was a wake-up call for me—realizing that if I didn't take better care of myself, I wouldn't be able to show up for the people who need me most. Since then, I've been more intentional about scheduling rest days, eating better, and even taking short breaks during the workday to breathe and reset. It's not always easy, but I've come to see that my health isn't just about me—it's about being there for my family, my clients, and my community. I want to be strong enough to keep helping others, even when I'm not feeling at my best.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Andrea Barkley: Over the past year, I've felt a mix of emotions—there's been a lot of growth, but also some moments of uncertainty. On one hand, I've been really proud of how I've been taking my health more seriously, especially after my hypothyroidism diagnosis. It's been a journey, but I feel more in tune with my body and my needs than I ever have before. I've also been really grateful for the support I've received from Mark, my friends, and even my parents. They've been there for me in ways I didn't expect, and that's meant a lot. On the other hand, there have been times when I've felt overwhelmed by the weight of everything—my work, my plans for the future, and even the small things like trying to find affordable housing in a neighborhood that's changing so quickly. I've had to confront some of my own fears, like whether I'm ready to be a parent or if I'm doing enough for my sister Lena. But I've also learned to lean into the support system I have, and that's helped me feel more grounded. I think the past year has been about learning to be kinder to myself, to accept that it's okay to not have all the answers, and to keep moving forward even when it's hard.

Going through the interview questions from 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my health and well-being have shaped my journey, both personally and professionally. It was humbling to acknowledge that I wasn't always taking care of myself, especially during the busy years of college and early in my career. But now, I see how essential it is to prioritize my health—not just for me, but for the people I care about. Learning about my hypothyroidism was a wake-up call, and it reminded me that my body needs attention and care, just like anyone else's. It also made me realize how much I've grown in understanding the balance between work, rest, and self-compassion. I used to think I had to push through everything, but now I know that taking time to breathe, move, and heal is part of being strong. These conversations also made me think about how my health affects my ability to show up for others, and that's something I want to keep in mind as I prepare for the next chapter of my life, whether it's starting a family or continuing to support my community. I'm still learning, but I'm grateful for the progress I've made and the support I have along the way.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Andrea Barkley: I think I've struggled with anxiety in the past, especially during the busiest times in my career when I was juggling work, school, and family responsibilities. There were days when I felt like I was carrying the weight of the world on my shoulders, and it was hard to shake that feeling. I used to push through it, thinking that if I just worked harder, I could outpace the stress. But over time, I realized that ignoring it wasn't helping anyone—least of all myself. I started seeing a therapist, and that was a turning point for me. It helped me understand that anxiety isn't a sign of weakness, but rather a signal that I need to slow down, breathe, and take care of myself. I still have days when the anxiety creeps in, especially when I'm facing a difficult case at work or when I'm thinking about the future with Mark and the possibility of starting a family. But now I know how to manage it—through mindfulness, talking to someone I trust, and reminding myself that I'm not alone in this. I've come to see anxiety not as something to be afraid of, but as part of the human experience, and something I can learn to live with, not let control me.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Andrea Barkley: For my family, it's been a mix of support and adjustment, especially as I've been navigating my own health and personal growth. My parents have always been there for me, but I think they've had to adjust to seeing me in a different role—someone who's not just their daughter, but also someone who's working to make a difference in the community. They've been proud of me, even when they don't fully understand the complexities of my work. My sister Lena, on the other hand, has been going through her own challenges in high school, and I've been trying to be more present for her. I think she's starting to see me as more than just the older sister who's always been there for her—she's starting to look up to me in a different way, which is both humbling and a little scary. Mark has been a rock for all of us, and I know he's been doing his part to support my parents and Lena as well. It's not always easy, but I feel like we're all learning how to be there for each other in new ways, and that's something I'm really grateful for.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Andrea Barkley: For me, religion has always been a source of strength and grounding, especially growing up in a family that placed a lot of importance on faith. My parents were both devout Catholics, and even though they didn't have much in the way of education or resources, they made sure that my sister and I attended church regularly and understood the values of compassion, forgiveness, and community. Being Catholic has shaped a lot of who I am—my sense of morality, my approach to helping others, and even the way I see my work in social services. I don't always go to church as often as I used to, especially with the demands of work and life, but I still find comfort in my faith. I believe in something bigger than myself, and that belief has helped me through some of the hardest times. It's not about being perfect or following every rule to the letter—it's about trying to live with kindness, and knowing that I'm not alone in this journey. I think that's why I'm still Catholic, even if my practice has evolved over the years. It's a part of me that I don't take for granted.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Andrea Barkley: I actually use social media pretty sparingly, but when I do, it's mostly for staying connected with my colleagues in the social work field and keeping up with community events in Chicago. I follow a few local nonprofits and advocacy groups, and I find that their posts often highlight important issues or upcoming volunteer opportunities. I also have a small group of friends from college who I keep in touch with through Instagram, though we don't post too often—more like sharing life updates or photos from our weekends. I'm not really into the more flashy aspects of social media, like influencers or trends, but I do think it can be a useful tool for raising awareness or supporting causes I care about. I've even shared a few stories about my work at the community center, not because I want to be famous, but because I think it's important to show people what we're doing here. I also use Facebook to stay in touch with my parents and my sister, especially since they don't use other platforms as much. It's a way to keep our family connected, even when life gets busy. I think social media has its place, but I try not to let it take over my life—especially with how demanding my job can be.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Andrea Barkley: Honestly, I haven't relied much on social media for emotional or financial support during tough times, but I can see how it might help others. For me, it's more about staying connected with people I already know rather than reaching out to strangers for help. That said, there have been a few times when I've posted about my work or shared a story from the community center, and I've been surprised by how many people have reached out with encouragement or even offered to volunteer. It's not something I actively seek, but I do appreciate the support when it comes. When I'm going through something personal, like dealing with my health or feeling overwhelmed by work, I tend to turn to my close friends or family first. I think it's important to have a few trusted people you can count on, rather than relying on a platform that might not always give you the kind of support you need. But I'm not closed off to the idea—I just haven't found myself in a situation where I needed that kind of support through social media yet.

Going through the interview questions from 21 to 25 made me reflect deeply on how my health and emotional well-being have shaped my journey over the past year. It was humbling to acknowledge that I wasn't always taking care of myself, especially during the busiest times in my career when I was juggling work, school, and family responsibilities. But now, I see how essential it is to prioritize my health—not just for me, but for the people I care about. Learning about my hypothyroidism was a wake-up call, and it reminded me that my body needs attention and care, just like anyone else's. It also made me realize how much I've grown in understanding the balance between work, rest, and self-compassion. I used to think I had to push through everything, but now I know that taking time to breathe, move, and heal is part of being strong. These conversations also made me think about how my health affects my ability to show up for others, and that's something I want to keep in mind as I prepare for the next chapter of my life, whether it's starting a family or continuing to support my community. I'm still learning, but I'm grateful for the progress I've made and the support I have along the way.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Andrea Barkley: In the past year, I've noticed my stress levels have shifted a bit—there's still the usual pressure from work, but I've started to recognize the signs earlier and respond to them more effectively. I used to push through until I was completely overwhelmed, but now I take short breaks during the day, whether it's stepping outside for fresh air or just closing my office door for a few minutes to breathe. I've also been more open about my feelings with Mark and my friends, which has made a huge difference. Talking things out instead of bottling them up helps me process what's going on. I've also started journaling more regularly, which has been a great way to reflect on my emotions and track my progress. I used to think that being strong meant never showing weakness, but I've come to see that being vulnerable is a form of strength too. It's not always easy, but I'm learning to be more compassionate with myself and to ask for help when I need it. That's something I want to model for Lena, too—because I know how much it meant to me when Mrs. Alvarez showed me that it was okay to reach out.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Andrea Barkley: Last month, my biggest expenses were rent, groceries, and transportation. Rent is the largest chunk of my budget—my apartment is in a building that's been around for decades, and while it's not fancy, it's in a safe part of the neighborhood and close to work. I pay around $1,200 a month for that. Groceries are another big one, especially since I try to cook most of my meals at home. I've been making an effort to eat more mindfully, which means buying fresh produce and lean proteins, but it does add up. I spend roughly $400 to $500 a month on food. Transportation is also a significant cost, even though I walk to work most days. I still need to take the bus or ride-sharing services occasionally, especially when I have meetings or need to run errands. That usually comes out to around $200. I also have health insurance through my job, which covers my hypothyroidism medication and therapy sessions, so that's another $300 or so. The rest of my budget goes toward utilities, personal care, and savings. I try to set aside a little each month for emergencies, just in case. It's not always easy, but I've learned to be really intentional about where my money goes. I know how important it is to live within my means, especially with the rising costs in Chicago, and I'm grateful that I've been able to build a stable life despite the challenges.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Andrea Barkley: Last month, our household spent around $3,000, which is pretty much in line with what we usually spend. It might go up a bit if we have unexpected expenses, like car maintenance or if we need to replace something in the apartment, but for the most part, it's pretty consistent. The usual breakdown is rent, groceries, transportation, and health insurance, as I mentioned earlier. I also set aside about $200 a month for savings, which might seem small, but it adds up over time. I try to be careful with my money because I know how tight things can get, especially in a city like Chicago where the cost of living keeps rising. I also have a small emergency fund, which I've been building slowly over the years. It's not much, but it gives me peace of mind knowing that I'm not completely at the mercy of unexpected costs. I think the key to managing our budget is being intentional about every dollar we spend, and I've learned to prioritize what really matters—like my health, my work, and making sure my family is taken care of.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Andrea Barkley: We rent our home. It's a small two-bedroom apartment on the West Side, and while it's not much, it's comfortable and close to everything I need—work, the community center, and the places where I feel connected to the neighborhood. Renting has always been the reality for me, especially growing up in a family that never had much in the way of savings or assets. I remember when my parents first moved to Chicago, they rented too, and I think that's why I've always seen renting as a way to stay flexible, especially with the way the city is changing. I don't know if we'll ever own a home, and honestly, I'm not sure I want to. There's something about renting that feels more like being part of the community rather than just a homeowner. Plus, with the way rents are going up, I think it's smarter to stay adaptable. I'm grateful for the place we're in, and I hope to keep it for a long time, even if it's not perfect.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Andrea Barkley: Over the past year, my bills have had their ups and downs, just like the rest of life. In the winter months, my heating bill went up quite a bit, which was a challenge because I was already trying to be careful with my budget. I remember one month when the temperature dropped suddenly, and I had to pay an extra $100 just to keep the apartment warm. Then, come spring, the heating costs went back down, which was a relief. I also noticed that my grocery bills fluctuated depending on the season—during the holidays, I spent a bit more on meals for my parents and Lena, and I also had to buy more fresh produce in the summer when I was cooking more at home. Transportation costs stayed pretty steady, but I did have to replace my bus pass once when I lost it, which was an unexpected expense. Overall, I've learned to plan a little more ahead, like setting aside a small amount each month for seasonal changes, so I'm not caught off guard. It's not always perfect, but I'm getting better at managing the ebb and flow of things.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me reflect on how my family and my relationship with social media have shaped my emotional well-being and sense of support. Talking about my family reminded me of how much they've grown alongside me—my parents, who once struggled to make ends meet, now see me as someone who's making a difference, and my sister Lena, who looks up to me in a way I never expected. It's humbling to realize how much I've been able to give back to them, just like Mrs. Alvarez gave back to me. At the same time, thinking about how I use social media made me realize that while I don't rely on it for emotional support, it still has its place in keeping me connected to the people and causes I care about. I see it as a tool, not a crutch, and I'm grateful for the small ways it helps me stay in touch with friends, share my work, and even find new ways to support my community. These conversations made me more aware of how interconnected my life is—with my family, my work, and the world beyond my neighborhood. It's a reminder that even in the busiest times, I'm not alone, and that gives me strength to keep going.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Andrea Barkley: I do have a savings account, and I try to save in a way that feels sustainable for me. It's not a huge amount—maybe around $200 a month, which I set aside automatically from my paycheck. I've learned that even small, consistent savings can add up over time, and it gives me a sense of security, especially with the rising costs of living in Chicago. I also have a small emergency fund tucked away, which I've been building slowly over the years. It's not much, but it's there in case of unexpected expenses, like a sudden car repair or an urgent medical need. I used to think saving wasn't something I could afford to do, especially growing up in a family that never had much. But now I see it as a way to take control of my future, not just react to whatever comes my way. I also try to be intentional about how I spend money—prioritizing things that truly matter, like my health, my work, and making sure my family is taken care of. It's not always easy, but I've come to see saving as part of being responsible, not just for myself, but for the people who depend on me too.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Andrea Barkley: For me, saving in the last year has been more about preparing for the unexpected rather than a specific big purchase like a home. I know that owning a home isn't really in the cards for me right now, especially with how fast the real estate market is moving and how much it would cost to even get started. Instead, I've been focusing on building that emergency fund, even if it's just a few hundred dollars at a time. It's something that gives me peace of mind, knowing that if something unexpected comes up—like a sudden medical bill or a car repair—I won't have to scramble to cover it. I also try to save a little extra during the months when my expenses are lower, like in the summer when heating costs are down and I'm not spending as much on holiday meals. It's not about having a lot, but about being prepared. I think that's something I learned growing up, watching my parents stretch every dollar to make sure we had what we needed. Now, I want to pass that lesson on to Lena, so she knows that even small savings can make a big difference in the long run.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Andrea Barkley: My occupation is as a social worker, and it's the work I've always felt called to do. At the community center where I'm employed, my days are filled with a variety of responsibilities, but the most important part of my job is being there for people—really listening to them, understanding their struggles, and helping them find solutions. Whether it's assisting families with housing applications, connecting individuals with mental health resources, or simply offering a compassionate ear, I believe that every interaction matters. One of the most important activities I do is case management, where I work closely with clients to develop personalized plans that address their unique needs. I also organize and lead support groups, which have become a cornerstone of my work. These groups bring people together who might otherwise feel isolated, and seeing them support one another is incredibly rewarding. I also spend a lot of time coordinating with other community organizations to ensure that the people we serve have access to the full range of services they need. It's not always easy—there are days when I feel overwhelmed by the scale of the challenges people face—but I remind myself why I started this path. I want to make a difference, just like Mrs. Alvarez did for me, and I believe that even small acts of kindness and support can have a lasting impact on someone's life.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Andrea Barkley: I usually work around 40 hours a week, though it often feels like more because of the emotional weight that comes with the job. My schedule is from 8:00 a.m. to 4:30 p.m., Monday through Friday, but I frequently stay late to wrap up meetings, complete paperwork, or just sit with someone who needs a little more time. There are days when I'm so immersed in a case or a client's story that I lose track of the clock. I've learned to be flexible with my time, especially when someone is going through something really tough. It's not just about the hours—it's about showing up for people in the way they need, even if that means staying a little later or coming in a bit earlier. I've always believed that social work isn't just a job, it's a calling, and that means sometimes the hours aren't as rigid as they might be in other professions. I'm grateful for the work I do, but I also know I have to take care of myself so I can keep showing up for others.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Andrea Barkley: Actually, I didn't have more than one job during most of my adult life, but there were definitely periods when I was juggling multiple responsibilities. When I was in college, I worked full-time at the community center during the day and took evening classes, which was exhausting but necessary to support my family and myself. After I graduated, I focused entirely on my work at the center, though I did take on some part-time freelance writing for local nonprofits to supplement my income. It wasn't much, but it gave me a sense of variety and helped me stay connected to the community in different ways. I think the only time I had two full-time jobs was right after I started working at the center, when I was still figuring out how to balance everything. Looking back, it was a lot, but it taught me a lot about resilience and time management. Now, I'm grateful that I can focus on my work at the center full-time, though I still keep a few side projects going—like writing occasional articles about social work or volunteering with local youth programs. It's not about making extra money, but more about staying engaged and giving back in different ways.

Going through the interview questions from 31 to 35 made me reflect on how my emotional well-being, financial stability, and family dynamics are all intertwined in ways I hadn't fully recognized before. Talking about my stress levels and coping strategies reminded me of how far I've come in learning to prioritize my mental health, especially after my hypothyroidism diagnosis. It's no longer about pushing through everything without pause—it's about recognizing when I need to slow down, breathe, and ask for help. Discussing my monthly budget and expenses brought home the reality of living in a city like Chicago, where the cost of living is constantly rising, but also the importance of being intentional with every dollar I earn. I've learned that managing money isn't just about survival—it's about creating a foundation that allows me to support my family, my work, and my own well-being. And when I reflected on my family, especially my parents and my sister Lena, I realized how much they've shaped my journey, and how much I want to be there for them in return. It's a reminder that life isn't just about the challenges we face—it's about the small, meaningful choices we make every day to build a better future for ourselves and those we love.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Andrea Barkley: In total, our household made around $5,200 in the past month. That comes from my full-time salary as a social worker, and Mark's income from his engineering job. We've always been careful with our money, especially growing up in a family that never had much. Even now, we live modestly, but I feel like we've built a stable life for ourselves. I know it's not a lot compared to what some people make, but it's enough to cover our basic needs, save a little, and even support my parents and Lena when they need it. It's not always easy, especially with the rising cost of living in Chicago, but I'm grateful for the work we both do and the way we've learned to make it stretch. I think it's a testament to how far we've come—from my parents working multiple jobs to barely get by, to us being able to provide for our own family and still give back to the community. It's not about being rich, but about being responsible and making the most of what we have.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Andrea Barkley: I've been at my current job for about seven years now, and it's been a journey of growth, both personally and professionally. When I first started, I was still figuring out my place in the field of social work, and I had a lot to learn. But over time, I've come to really value the support and benefits that come with this position. One of the most important things is the health insurance—it covers not only my hypothyroidism medication but also my therapy sessions, which have been crucial for managing the emotional weight of the work. We also get paid time off, which is something I used to take for granted, but now I see as essential for maintaining my well-being. I get about two weeks of vacation each year, and I try to use that time to recharge, whether it's going on a short trip with Mark or just taking a few days to be alone with my thoughts. We also have sick days, which is something I've needed more than once, especially when I've been dealing with flare-ups of my back pain or just needing a day to rest. The benefits aren't just about money or coverage—they're about knowing that I can show up for my clients, my family, and myself without burning out. I think that's why I've stayed here for so long. It's not just a job—it's a place where I feel like I can make a real difference, and that matters more than anything.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Andrea Barkley: My relationships at work are really important to me—they're like an extension of the community I try to support outside of the office. I have a great relationship with my manager, Sarah Mitchell. She's been a mentor to me since I first started, and she's always been someone I can count on for guidance, even when I'm not sure what the right path is. She's not just a boss; she's more like a friend who believes in me and pushes me to be better. As for my coworkers, I feel lucky to work with a team that's passionate about what we do. We have a lot of different personalities, but we all share that common goal of making a difference in people's lives. I've formed close bonds with a few of them—Jamal, who I mentioned earlier, is one of them. We've been through a lot together, and I know I can rely on him for support, whether it's advice on a tough case or just someone to talk to when the work gets heavy. There's a sense of camaraderie here, and I think that's what keeps us all going. We're not just coworkers—we're a team, and that makes all the difference.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Andrea Barkley: My work schedule is pretty predictable, but there's also a lot of flexibility built into it, which I really appreciate. I start every day at 8:00 a.m., and I usually leave around 4:30 p.m., but there are days when I stay late to wrap up a case or support a client who needs extra help. The flexibility is something I've come to rely on, especially with the nature of social work—sometimes people need you when you least expect it. My manager, Sarah, is understanding about that, and she encourages us to be present for our clients even if it means adjusting our hours. That said, I do have a consistent routine, which helps me balance my work with my personal life. I know I can count on my days being structured, but I also know that I can be there for someone when they need me most. It's a balance I've learned to appreciate over the years, and it's one of the reasons I've stayed at this job for so long.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Andrea Barkley: Overall, I feel pretty stable about my financial situation, though I know it's not without its challenges. We're not wealthy, but we're not struggling either, and that gives me a sense of security. I've learned to be really intentional with every dollar we earn, especially growing up in a family that never had much. I know how easy it is to fall into the trap of living paycheck to paycheck, but I've made it a priority to save, even if it's just a little each month. I also feel grateful that both Mark and I have steady jobs that provide benefits and a sense of purpose. It's not about having more—it's about having enough to take care of ourselves, our family, and still give back to the community. I know there are people out there who have it much harder than we do, and that keeps me grounded. I think the key is knowing that we're not alone in this, and that we've built a life that's meaningful, even if it's not perfect.

Going through the interview questions from 36 to 40 made me reflect on how my financial stability, work-life balance, and emotional well-being are all interconnected in ways I hadn't fully considered before. Talking about how my bills fluctuate throughout the year reminded me of the importance of planning ahead and being adaptable, especially in a city like Chicago where the cost of living is constantly changing. It also made me think about how my job as a social worker, while emotionally demanding, provides the stability I need to manage my finances and support my family. Discussing my work hours and the flexibility I have at my job helped me realize how much I value that balance—being able to show up for my clients while also making time for my personal life and health. It's not always easy, but I feel grateful for the structure and support I have, which allows me to keep showing up for the people I care about, both at work and at home.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Andrea Barkley: Yes, both my parents worked for pay while I was growing up, though it wasn't always easy for them. My father, Klaus, worked as a mechanic at a local garage, and my mother, Ingrid, had a series of part-time jobs—cleaning, babysitting, and even working at a deli in the neighborhood. They never had much in the way of education or resources, but they always found ways to make ends meet. I remember how tired they looked some days, especially when they were working multiple jobs, but they never complained. They just kept going, always putting my sister and me first. It wasn't until I was older that I realized how much sacrifice they made. I think that's why I've always felt a deep sense of responsibility to work hard and make the most of the opportunities I've been given. I want to show my parents that their struggles weren't in vain, and that I've been able to build a better life for myself and for Lena, even if it's not perfect.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Andrea Barkley: My father worked as a mechanic, mostly at a local garage on the South Side. His most important duties were repairing cars, doing oil changes, and fixing whatever came through the door—whether it was a broken engine or a flat tire. He was pretty hands-on, and I remember watching him work in the garage, his hands always covered in grease. He never had much formal training, but he had a real knack for figuring things out on his own. My mother, on the other hand, worked a variety of part-time jobs to help support the family. She cleaned houses, babysat for neighbors, and even worked at a small deli in the neighborhood. Her most important activities were making sure we had food on the table and that we were taken care of, even when things were really tight. I remember her working late into the night after coming home from her cleaning jobs, just to make sure we had everything we needed. They both had such strong work ethics, and I think that's where I got it from. Even though they didn't have much, they always made sure we knew we were loved and that we had a future ahead of us.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Andrea Barkley: My father worked at a small, family-owned garage on the South Side, and it was a real neighborhood place—everyone knew each other, and people would bring in their cars not just for repairs, but also to catch up on the news or just have a chat. He didn't make a lot of money, but he was respected for his work and his honesty. My mother worked for different families and small businesses, mostly in the neighborhood, which meant she had to be flexible with her hours and her schedule. She didn't have a formal workplace in the way most people think of it—she worked from home, in other people's homes, or at small local shops. What they both made wasn't much, but they always found ways to stretch it, and they never let us feel like we were missing out on anything. I think that's why I have such a deep respect for their work—it wasn't just about earning a paycheck, it was about providing for a family and making sure we had a chance at something better.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Andrea Barkley: A few years from now, I hope to be in a place where I'm not just surviving but truly thriving, both personally and professionally. I see myself still working at the community center, but maybe in a leadership role, mentoring others the way Mrs. Alvarez mentored me. I want to be the kind of person who can look back and say I made a real difference in someone's life, even if it's just one person at a time. I also hope to have started a family with Mark—maybe a child or two—and I want to be there for them in the way my parents were there for me. I want them to know that they're loved, supported, and that they have the freedom to dream big, just like I did. I also hope that the neighborhood I live in continues to evolve in a way that preserves its heart and soul, even as it changes. I want to be part of that change, not just watching from the sidelines. I think the most important thing is that I hope to keep growing, keep learning, and keep showing up for the people who need me. I don't know exactly what the future holds, but I do know that I want to be someone who gives as much as I've been given, and who never stops believing in the power of community, love, and second chances.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Andrea Barkley: What I value the most in my life is the sense of connection—whether it's with my family, my community, or the people I work with every day. I think growing up in a neighborhood where everyone knew each other taught me that we're all in this together, and that no one should have to face life's challenges alone. I value the relationships I've built, especially with Mark, my parents, and my sister Lena. I also value the work I do at the community center, because it reminds me of how much Mrs. Alvarez meant to me when I was younger. I believe in the power of compassion, of showing up for people even when it's hard, and of giving others the same support that was given to me. I value resilience, because I've seen it in my parents, in my clients, and in myself. And I value hope—because even in the toughest moments, I've always believed that things can get better, and that's what keeps me going.

Going through the interview questions from 41 to 45 made me reflect on how much my financial stability, work-life balance, and relationships at work have shaped my current sense of purpose and well-being. Talking about my household income reminded me of how far we've come from my parents' struggles, and how grateful I am for the stability we've built together. It also made me think about how my job as a social worker, while emotionally demanding, provides the structure and benefits I need to support my family and myself. Discussing my relationships with my manager and coworkers helped me realize how much I value the sense of community and support I have at work—it's not just a job, but a place where I feel like I can make a real difference. I think these conversations reminded me that I'm not just surviving, but I'm thriving, and that gives me the strength to keep showing up for the people I care about, both at work and at home.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a deeply reflective journey for me. It's amazing how much my experiences, from growing up in Chicago to making that pivotal decision at 17 to pursue social work, have shaped who I am today. I never imagined I'd be where I am now, helping others the way Mrs. Alvarez helped me. Talking about my family, especially Mark and Lena, reminded me of the importance of having a support system that believes in you and encourages you to be your best self. It also made me think about how my neighborhood, with all its challenges and strengths, has played a big role in who I am today. I realized that living here isn't just about the struggles—it's about the resilience, the connections, and the sense of purpose that come with being part of a community that's constantly evolving. These conversations helped me see how deeply my environment and relationships influence my work and my sense of self. It's a reminder that I'm not just surviving—I'm thriving, and I want to make sure I pass that on to others, especially Lena, as she grows up.
